subject: Re: Utter/Ado
msgSnippet: Speaking of large groups (Nigerian-English mentioned in the article) - Philippino-English is large and common in the US: pried pish (fried fish), ting you
messageBody:
Speaking of large groups (Nigerian-English mentioned in the article) -
Philippino-English is large and common in the US: pried pish (fried
fish), ting you berry muds (thank you very much).

Thus, I recommend adhering to some historic spellings just for clarity
- as in differentiating among sight, site & cite ("to sight the text"
is as meaningful as "to cite the text" - or "I sight the site")...

--- In Read_Alphabet@yahoogroups.com, Benct Philip Jonsson <bpj@...>
wrote:
>
> All of you discussing how to adapt QS to
> different accents should make sure to read
> this article:
>
> <http://www.phon.ucl.ac.uk/home/wells/accents_spellingreform.htm>
